citation.article-title: Taxonomic position of Campylobacter cryaerophila sp. nov.

p.s: Description of Campylobacter cryaerophila sp. nov.
Campylobacter cryaerophila (cry.ae.ro.philá. Gr. adj. cry cold; Gr. n. aero air; L. adj. phila fond of; cryaerophila fond of cold and air)
Cells are gram-negative nonsporeforming rods (0.4 μm wide by 1.8 μm long); unusually long cells (>20 μm) have been observed.
Cells are usually curved, S shaped, or helical.
Darting motility; single polar flagella (amphitricate).
Growth occurs at 30°C, and colonies grown under reduced oxygen tension for 48 to 72 h are small (1 mm in diameter), smooth, and convex with entire edges.
Colonies may become flattened and irregular and may vary in size.
Strains in subculture grow in air, in air containing 10% CO2, and anaerobically.
Some strains grow between 5 and 40°C, but all strains grow at 15°C.
The strains are positive for catalase and oxidase activities and reduce nitrate (98.6% of the strains) and nitrite (85.9%).
The strains are tolerant to 2% NaCl, 4% glucose, 0.1% glycine, and pteridine vibriostatic compound 0/129.
The strains do not grow in medium containing 1.0% glycine and 1 mg of 2,3,5-triphenyl tetrazolium chloride per ml, and sodium selenite is not reduced.
No H2S is produced in triple sugar iron medium or medium containing cystine.
The strains produce alkaline reactions in Hugh-Leifson medium.

All strains are negative in methyl red and Voges-Proskauer tests and do not produce indole, ornithine, lysine, and arginine decorboxylases, urease, ribonuclease, or deoxyribonuclease (97.9% of the strains).
The strains do not utilize citrate, malonate, or gluconate, do not liquify serum or gelatin, and do not hydrolyze czfsein, starch, hippurate, tributyrin, or esculin.
Growth does not occur in KCN or on deoxycholate agar, and all strains fail to catabolize carbohydrates.
The strains are susceptible to nalidixic acid (40 μg/ml) and resistant to carbenicillin (64 μg/ml).
Strains have been isolated from reproductive tracts and aborted fetuses of several species of farm animals, from animal feces, and from milk of mastitis cows.
The mean G+C content is 31 t 1 mol%.
Strain A169/B (= 02766) is the type strain of C. cryaerophila and has been deposited in the National Collection of Type Cultures as strain NCTC 11885.
This strain conforms to the description given above for the species with respect to morphology and growth characteristics.
No growth occurs below 5°C or above 37°C; the optimum growth temperature is 30°C.
Strain A169/BT (T = type strain) is catalase and oxidase positive and reduces nitrate and nitrite.
Methyl red and Voges-Proskauer tests are negative, and indole is not produced; ornithine, lysine, and arginine decarboxylases, urease, ribonuclease, and deoxyribonuclease are not produced.
Citrate, malonate, and gluconate are not utilized; serum and gelatin are not liquified, and casein, starch, hippurate, tributyrin, and esculin are not hydrolyzed.
No acid is produced from carbohydrates.
No reaction is produced in litmus milk or Crossley milk, and an alkaline reaction occurs in Hugh-Leifson medium.
Growth occurs on medium containing 8% glucose and pteridine vibriostatic compound 0/129.
No growth occurs on medium containing >2% NaCl, 1.0% glycine, or 1 mg of 2,3,5-triphenyl tetrazolium chloride per ml.
Sodium selenite is not reduced, and no H2S is produced in triple sugar iron medium or medium supplemented with cystine.
No growth occurs on McConkey or desoxycholate agar.

Antibiotic susceptibility: resistant to ampicillin (18 μg/ml), carbenicillin (64 μg/ml), chloramphenicol (4 μg/ml), dimetridazole (1 μg/ml), kanamycin (2 μg/ml), metronidazole (8 μg/ml), nalidixic acid (5 μg/ml), penicillin G (1 IU/ml), and polymyxin B (2 μg/ml); susceptible to strkptomycin (12 μg/ml).
The G+C content of the type strain is 31.5 mol%.
Strain A169/BT was isolated from an aborted bovine fetus.
